Angel Falls.passage: Angel Falls (Spanish: Pico de las Angles) is a waterfall on the Angel River (Spanish: Río Angel), in Canaima National Park in Bolivia, at an altitude of 3,724 m (12,300 ft). The waterfall is named after the pilot of the first airplane to fly over its summit, Charles Edward Fay, who had a vision of the Virgin Mary there, hence the name "Angel". The waterfall is the highest uninterrupted vertical fall and the highest free-falling waterfall in the world, dropping a total of 778 m (2,549 ft) from the Pico Puncu (3,050 m; 9,900 ft) to the Pico Raza (2,700 m; 9,000 ft), with an average descent speed of 1,212 m/minute (3,950 ft/minute). The volume of water is estimated to be between 3,000 and 5,000 m3 (200 and 300 million US gal) per second. The Angel Falls, which are formed by the convergence of the Ríos Caroní and Yapacana, have a total drop of 3,212 m (10,500 ft), and are the world's second highest waterfall.

Christ the Redeemer.passage: Christ the Redeemer is a statue of Jesus Christ located in Corcovado mountain in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil. The statue stands at 30 meters tall, and is located at the top of the mountain at an altitude of approximately 850 m (2,789 ft). The statue was carved by Italian artist, Gian Lorenzo Bernini. The statue was inaugurated on 12 October 1931, the 700th anniversary of the arrival of the Portuguese in Brazil, hence the name of the statue: Christ the Redeemer. The statue is a symbol of Rio de Janeiro and Brazil, and is one of the New Seven Wonders of the World. The statue is the largest monolith statue in the world, and the largest statue of Jesus, the largest carved statue in the world. The Christ the Redeemer statue has become a symbol of Rio de Janeiro and Brazil, and is one of the most visited monuments in the world, with approximately 20,000 people climbing to the top each day. The statue is located at the top of the mountain, on a 2,700-foot (830-meter) granite promontory, Corcovado. The statue is approximately 30 meters (98 ft) tall, and weighs approximately 15 short tons (13 t). The statue's location, on the side of a mountain, gives it an impressive view of Rio de Janeiro.

Eiffel Tower.passage: The Eiffel Tower is a wrought iron lattice tower on the Champ de Mars in Paris, France. It was built by Gustave Eiffel as the entrance arch for the World's Fair in 1889. It was later named as one of the Seven Wonders of the Modern World by the American Society of Civil Engineers. The tower stands 324 metres (1,063 ft) tall and has three levels. The first level is a platform at the base of the tower, the second level consists of a series of metal arches that support the tower, and the top level features two observatories, a restaurant, a gift shop, and an open-air observation deck at 300 metres (980 ft) above ground level. The tower is the tallest structure in Paris, France, and the seventh-tallest in France, and the second tallest structure in France after the Mont Blanc. The Eiffel Tower is one of the most-visited monuments in the world, with over 7 million people visiting it annually, making it the most-visited paid monument in the world. It has become one of the most recognizable symbols of France, and is frequently featured in popular culture, including films, television shows, songs, and other cultural works.

Great Pyramid of Giza.passage: The Great Pyramid of Giza (Arabic: مبدأ الكوكب الجملي‎, romanized: Mabdā al-Kūkb al-ǧamlī; also known as the Pyramid of Cheops) is the oldest and largest of the three pyramids in the Giza necropolis bordering the city of Cairo, Egypt, and the largest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. It is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still in existence, and the only one still partially intact, having been constructed over a period of around 20 years from 2560 BC to 2540 BC. The Great Pyramid is the largest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World. The Great Pyramid is the largest of the three pyramids in the Giza Necropolis. The Great Pyramid was the tallest man-made structure in the world for over 3,800 years, until the completion of the Lincoln Cathedral in 1300. The Great Pyramid is the oldest of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World still in existence, and the only one still partially intact. Hagia Sophia.passage: Hagia Sophia (Turkish: "Aya Sofya" meaning "Holy Wisdom" or "Church of the Divine Wisdom") is a former imperial basilica and later cathedral that was the main church of the Ottoman capital of Constantinople (modern-day Istanbul) and the seat of the Patriarch of Constantinople. The building was constructed in the sixth century, on the spot of a church built during the reign of Emperor Justinian. The church was constructed during the reign of Emperor Justinian (r. 527–565), and named in his honor. It was built in the form of a cross, with a dome over the eastern arm and a smaller dome over the southern arm. The building was encircled by two rows of columns, and had three main doors, one in the western façade, one in the northern, and the other one in the southern façade. The church was converted into a mosque during the reign of the Ottoman Sultan Mehmed the Conqueror (r. 1451–1481) and renamed "Hagia Sophia". It was later converted into a museum and currently houses the İç Kale (Inner Palace) of the Turkish Presidential Palace. The building is considered one of the finest examples of Byzantine architecture and is a World Heritage Site. The church is located in the Sultanahmet district of Istanbul, on the site of a Roman temple and a basilica erected in 360 AD.

qae_pairs.explanation: The capital of the country where Hagia Sophia is located is Istanbul.

qae_pairs.explanation: Justinian

Machu Picchu.passage: Machu Picchu (Quechua: Machupicchu; "Old Mountain" or "Old Peak"), sometimes called the Lost City of the Incas, is the most famous of the Inca sites in the Cusco Region of Peru. The Incas built Machu Picchu as an estate for the Pachacútec Inca, and it was abandoned around the time of the Spanish conquest. The site is located 2,430 metres (7,970 ft) above sea level and is considered sacred by the local people. The Incas called the site "Pucara" or "P'ukara", meaning "Ghost" or "Spook" in Quechua. It was built on the eastern slopes of the mountain known locally as Huayna Picchu. The site was not rediscovered until 1911, when an American named Hiram Bingham was guided to it by a local farmer, who told him the location after being frightened by the sight of Bingham's mule. Bingham's 1911 visit was the first of many by archaeologists. In 1985, Machu Picchu was designated a World Heritage Site. It has become one of the most-visited tourist destinations in Peru.

qae_pairs.question: Who was the first person to visit Machu Picchu?
qae_pairs.explanation: Hiram Bingham was the first person to visit Machu Picchu.

qae_pairs.explanation: Machu Picchu is located in Peru.

Petra.passage: Petra ( /ˈpɛtrə/ PETR-ə, Arabic: ٱلْـمُصــرَّـــة‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎ ‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎‏‎) is a historical and archaeological city in the southern Jordanian governorate of Ma'an, 9.6 kilometers (6 mi) east-southeast of Amman. It was built by the Nabataeans in the 1st century BC as the Nabataean capital, and served as the capital of the Arab tribe of the Quraysh in pre-Islamic Arabia.

Taj Mahal.passage: Taj Mahal is a 17th-century mausoleum on the south bank of the Yamuna River in the Indian city of Agra. It was commissioned by the Mughal Emperor, Shah Jahan, in memory of his third wife, Mumtaz Mahal, who died during the birthing of their fourteenth child, Gauhar. The building is the culmination of Mughal architecture and is widely considered the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally renowned masterpieces of the world's heritage. It has been described by the United Nations as "the jewel of Muslim art in India and one of the universally renowned masterpieces of the world's heritage". The monument is the ultimate example of Mughal architecture and is widely considered the most beautiful building in the world. Uluru.passage: Uluru, also known as Ayers Rock, is a large sandstone rock formation in the southern part of the Northern Territory, in the central desert of Australia. The nearest large town is Alice Springs, some 450 km (280 mi) away. Uluru, which has a number of local Aboriginal names (such as Ayers Rock and Kata Tjuta), is a prominent landmark in the area, and has long been considered sacred by the local indigenous people. It is often described as the most prominent feature in the Outback and is a common symbol of the Australian Outback, while the nearby town of Alice Springs takes its name from its proximity to the rock. Uluru rises dramatically above the surrounding plain, and is one of the most recognizable landmarks in Australia, depicted on the country's coat of arms. The traditional owners of Uluru, the Pitjantjatjara and Yankunytjatjara peoples, have had joint management of the site since 1985. Uluru is a monolith composed of alternating layers of hard and softer rock. The top of the rock is flat and measures 2.4 km (1.5 mi) by 1.8 km (1.1 mi). The rock is surrounded by a rugged sandstone plateau, and measures 20 m (66 ft) high at its highest point.

qae_pairs.explanation: Pitjantjatjara and Yankunytjatjara

qae_pairs.explanation: The traditional owners of Uluru, the Pitjantjatjara and Yankunytjatjara peoples, had joint management of the site since 1985.

Angel of the North.passage: Angel of the North is an outdoor sculpture and artwork in Gateshead, England. The work, by Antony Gormley, was commissioned by the Tyne and Wear Development Corporation in 1997 to be sited at Gateshead Millennium Bridge, a pedestrian and cyclist bridge crossing the River Tyne. Gormley was chosen from over 2,000 entries from around the world, and the sculpture took him two years to create. The work consists of an, stainless steel frame supporting a  acrylic wing. The sculpture was unveiled on 1 January 1998.

the Angel River.passage: The Angel River is a tributary of the Fraser River in the Canadian province of British Columbia. Charles Edward Fay.passage: Charles Edward Fay (1863–1916) was an American botanist, born in Philadelphia. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania in 1883, and was a professor of botany at the University of Kansas from 1885 to 1901. He was a member of the Botanical Society of America, and was the author of "The Ferns of North America" (1903).

Bolivia.passage: Bolivia (Spanish: "Bolivia" ), officially the Plurinational State of Bolivia (Spanish: "Estado Plurinacional de Bolivia" ), is a landlocked country located in western-central South America. Paris.passage: Paris (French: [paʁiʒ]; Parisian French: /paʁiʒ/) is the capital and most populous city of France, with an area of 105 square kilometres (41 square miles) and a population of 2,229,621 as of January 2020. The city is both a commune and department, and its residents are called Parisians. The Paris region has an important place in France's economy, ranking as one of the world's major global economic centers.

the Mont Blanc.passage: The Mont Blanc massif, also known as the Mont Blanc Range, is a mountain range in the Alps, extending for about 60 km (37 mi) between the Col du Géant and the Simplon Pass in Switzerland. It includes the highest mountain of Western Europe, the eponymous Mont Blanc, and is bounded by the valleys of the Arve and Dora. It is located on the Franco-Swiss and Italian-Swiss borders, and the highest point of the range, the Pointe des Ecrêtres, is located on the border between France and Italy. The massif is composed of three distinct subranges: the Grandes Jorasses (4,810 m, 15,780 ft), the Dent Blanche (4,810 m, 15,780 ft) and the Aiguille du Tour (4,770 m, 15,685 ft).

qae_pairs.question: What is the highest point of the Mont Blanc massif?

Cairo.passage: Cairo (i/kæˈrɔɪ/; Arabic: كاريو, romanized: كَرِيْو, IPA: [kˤaːrˤiː], Egyptian Arabic: كَرْيُو, IPA: [ˈkɾj.uːˈwi]) is the capital city of Egypt. It stands on the east bank of the Nile River, across which sits Giza, a suburb of Cairo.

Egypt.passage: Egypt (i/ɛˈdʒɪbi/, i/ɛˈdʒaɪbi/, i/əˈdʒɪbi/; Arabic: مصر, romanized: Miṣr, Egyptian Arabic: مصر, romanized: Misr; Egyptian pronunciation: (ˈmizr)), officially the Arab Republic of Egypt (Egyptian Arabic: جمهورية مصر العربية, romanized: Jamaʿa Misr al-ʿArabīyah), is a transcontinental country spanning the northeast corner of Africa and southwest corner of Asia by a land bridge formed by the Sinai Peninsula. Egypt has a population of over 100 million, making it the most populous country on the African continent and the eleventh-most populous country in the world. The great majority of its estimated 83 million inhabitants live near the banks of the Nile River, with the densely populated Nile Delta accounting for about 87% of the countrys total land area and over half of its population. About another 15% of the population lives in the north around Alexandria, the port city on the Mediterranean Sea. Egypt is a sovereign state located in the northern hemisphere and almost entirely situated on the alluvial Nile River floodplain. The capital city is Cairo, which is also the largest city in the Arab world.

qae_pairs.question: Which city in Egypt is the capital of the country?
qae_pairs.explanation: Cairo is the capital city of Egypt.

Justinian.passage: Justinian I (Latin: Flavius Petrus Sabbatius Justinianus Augustus; c. 482 – 17 August 565) was the emperor of the Byzantine Empire from 527 to 565. Justinian was the last emperor to rule the entire Roman Empire, as well as being a legislator, theologian, and jurist, and is considered one of the most successful and significant Roman emperors. He was born in Illyricum (modern-day Croatia) to a noble family of modest means, and rose through the imperial hierarchy due to his exceptional intelligence, political skill, and tenacity. Justinian's reign saw the first formal codification of Roman law, and he played a major role in the development of the Catholic Church into the world's premier religious institution, as well as in the preservation and development of Medieval Greek philosophy and the Eastern liturgy.

Peru.passage: Peru (Spanish for "Land of Silver"; Quechua: Piruw or Pirus) is a country located in western South America, bordering Ecuador to the north, Brazil to the northeast, Chile to the east, Colombia to the southeast, and Bolivia to the west. It is sometimes referred to as the "Land of the Incas", although the Incas only controlled the area within the current borders of Peru for a short period. Peru is home to diverse wildlife, including the Inca bear, the spectacled bear, and the Andean condor.

the Cusco Region.passage: The Cusco Region is one of the sixteen regions of the Republic of Peru. Its capital is the city of Cusco. It is bordered on the north and northeast by the Cajamarca Region, on the east and southeast by the Pasco Region, on the southwest by the Puno Region, and on the west by the Amazonas Region. It is home to the ancient Inca capital of Cusco and the city of Paucartambo, as well as the Colca Canyon.

Quechua.passage: Quechua, also known by its autonym Runasimi (Aymara: Ῥunasu), is an indigenous language of the Andes. It is mainly spoken in South America by over 10 million people in Peru, Ecuador, Bolivia and Argentina, as well as by a small number of people in the United States. Quechuan languages are spoken in a region that covers most of Peru and parts of Bolivia, Argentina, Ecuador and Chile. The Quechuan family is divided into three branches, namely Huillichean, Cajamarcan and Cañar–Cosanga. The Quechuan languages are not mutually intelligible, although some are more closely related to each other than others. Quechuan languages are also related to Aymara, which is spoken in Bolivia, Peru, and Chile. Quechua was the language of the Inca Empire, which dominated the area from the 15th to the 16th centuries. Quechua has also been used as a second language for communication between Spanish speakers and Quechua speakers, and Quechua is currently taught in some schools of Peru and Bolivia, where it is a subject in the primary and secondary education curricula. The term "Quechua" is also used to refer to the Quechua language, and to the Quechua people, who are the indigenous people of the Andes.

qae_pairs.question: Which language is not related to Quechua?
qae_pairs.explanation: Aymara

India.passage: India (i/ˈaɪnˌdʒəˌ/), officially the Republic of India (rɪˈbɒfən iti ˈɡænə), is a country in South Asia. It is the seventh-largest country by area, the second-most populous country (with over 1.2 billion people), and the most populous democracy in the world. It is bounded by the Indian Ocean on the south, the Arabian Sea on the south-east, and the Bay of Bengal on the south-west. It shares land borders with Pakistan to the west; China, Nepal, and Bhutan to the north-east; and Myanmar (Burma) to the east. In the Indian Ocean, India is in the vicinity of Sri Lanka and the Maldives. India's Andaman and Nicobar Islands share a maritime border with Thailand and Indonesia.

Mumtaz Mahal.passage: Mumtaz Mahal (Urdu: مُمْتَز مَہال, Hindi: मुमताज महल, "Pearl Palace"; 22 January 1593–17 June 1631) was the only wife of Mughal Emperor Shah Jahan, and the empress of the Mughal Empire from 1627 until her death in 1631. She was the daughter of Asad ud-Din Muhammad Khan, a nobleman of the Kabul Subah of the Mughal Empire, and his first wife, Bibi Bahu. She was the granddaughter of Sher Shah Suri and the niece of Khwaja Khizr Sultan. She married Shah Jahan in 1612 when the latter was aged twenty-three and he was thirty-one. She was a devout Muslim and a skilled poet. She is considered a tragic figure in the history of the Mughal Empire, who is remembered for her beauty, loyalty, and tragic death. She was the only Mughal empress to die in the harem of the Red Fort in Delhi. Her death occurred during the birth of their 14th child and 13th daughter, Gauharara Begum. Her death is traditionally held to have occurred either from a postpartum haemorrhage or from a sepsis infection.

the United Nations.passage: The United Nations (UN) is an intergovernmental organization to promote international co-operation. A replacement for the ineffective League of Nations, the organization was established on 24 October 1945 after World War II to promote world peace and security, and was originally called the "United Nations Organization". The current headquarters of the United Nations is in Manhattan, New York City, on the east side of Midtown Manhattan. The organization has played a decisive role in conflicts such as the Korean War and the Cold War. It is the most prominent intergovernmental body in the world, and is sometimes described as the "world government", "world administration" or "world government body".

the Northern Territory.passage: Northern Territory, officially the Northern Territory of Australia, is a federal Australian territory in the continent of Australia. The territory has an area of 1,852,400 square kilometres (708,400 sq mi), making it the second-largest Australian jurisdiction, after Western Australia. It is bordered by Queensland to the east and New South Wales to the north, and its coastline extends for about 3,500 kilometres (2,200 mi) along the Timor and Arafura Seas. The territory is often referred to by its nickname, "the Territory". The population of the Northern Territory was 250,000 in June 2021, with the capital city being Darwin. The population is concentrated along the coast, where most of the territory's population of 244,000 people live. The population density of the Northern Territory is 3.3 people per square kilometre.

qae_pairs.explanation: The Northern Territory is larger than Western Australia.

qae_pairs.explanation: The capital city of the Northern Territory is Darwin.

Alice Springs.passage: Alice Springs is the capital city of the Northern Territory of Australia. It is located in Central Australia, within the traditional lands of the Arrernte people. It is the administrative, commercial, and cultural centre for the central desert region of Australia, and is the fourth-largest inland urban area in the nation.

qae_pairs.question: Alice Springs is the largest city in what region of Australia?

Ayers Rock.passage: Ayers Rock is a large sandstone rock formation that forms a prominent landmark on the landscape of the Australian continent. It is situated in the southern Simpson Desert, about 500 kilometres (300 mi) north of Alice Springs, and about 200 kilometres (120 mi) west of the nearest town, Yulara, in the central Australian outback, and is a well known landmark in Central Australia. Ayers Rock is the traditional name given to the formation by Indigenous Australian peoples, and it has also been known as Uluru, originally an Aboriginal word that has been translated as \"red rock\". The rock has also been referred to as \"the big white thing\". The traditional owners of the area, the Anangu peoples, consider it to be a sacred site and they ask that it be referred to as such. The rock was first named \"Ayers Rock\" by the explorer Ernest Giles in 1873, who thought he had found gold on it. The rock is the most sacred site for the local Pitjantjatjara Aboriginal peoples. The site has been declared a national park and is a popular tourist destination. The nearest town is Yulara, located on the traditional lands of the Anangu people.

qae_pairs.explanation: Ernest Giles was the first person to name the rock Ayers Rock.

Gateshead.passage: Gateshead is a metropolitan borough of Tyne and Wear, England, located on the north bank of the River Tyne. The borough was formed in 1974 by the merger of the former county borough of Gateshead with part of the County of Durham, including Chester-le-Street, and most of Jarrow and Hebburn. The population of the borough at the 2011 UK census was 199,500, reducing marginally to 199,388 at the 2019 census.
